questions.question: What is the effect of photoisomerization on the magnetic properties of a dysprosium-based single-molecule magnet?
questions.answer: Photoisomerization induces a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation that can modulate the magnetic relaxation behavior of the dysprosium-based single-molecule magnet, as observed in the change from compound 1c to 1o.

questions.question: How does the synthesis process of compound 1c differ when using ligand Lo compared to ligand Lc?
questions.answer: The synthesis process of compound 1c involves layering a solution of [Dy(Tppy)F(pyridine)2]PF6 dissolved in dichloromethane with a dichloromethane solution of ligand Lc, resulting in the formation of blue prism-shaped crystals. In contrast, attempts to repeat the crystallization procedure with ligand Lo did not result in solid material formation.

questions.question: True or False: The magnetic hysteresis data for compounds 1c and 1o show identical behavior at temperatures as low as 0.5 K.
What computational methods were used to investigate the electronic structure and magnetic properties of compounds 1c and 1o?
questions.answer: Wavefunction theory calculations, including CASSCF and RASSI approaches, were used to investigate the electronic structure and magnetic properties of compounds 1c and 1o.

questions.question: What changes occur in the unit cell parameters of compound 1c upon irradiation with 532 nm light?
questions.answer: Irradiation of compound 1c with 532 nm light results in a color change from dark blue to colorless and variation in the unit cell parameters, leading to an overall volume increase.

questions.question: How does the magnetic relaxation behavior of compound 1o compare to that of compound 1c?
questions.answer: Compound 1o exhibits faster low-temperature relaxation than compound 1c, which is apparent in magnetic hysteresis data collected for both compounds.

questions.question: True or False: The principal magnetic axis orientation is significantly different between compounds 1c and 1o.
What role does the Dy–F bond play in the magnetic anisotropy of the dysprosium-based single-molecule magnets?
questions.answer: The very short Dy–F bond is preserved upon exchange of the pyridine ligand with bispyridyl dithienylethene, contributing to the strong axial magnetic anisotropy and the slow magnetic relaxation characteristics of the chain compound.

questions.question: True or False: The synthesis of compound 1c results in a 100% yield.
What experimental techniques were used to characterize the structural and magnetic properties of compounds 1c and 1o?
questions.answer: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction, photocrystallography, magnetic susceptibility measurements, and variable-field magnetization data collection were used to characterize the structural and magnetic properties of compounds 1c and 1o.
